head.title: Summit-Bound, Barak Survives A Vote at Home

hedline.hl1: Summit-Bound, Barak Survives A Vote at Home

abstract.p: Israeli Prime Min Ehud Barak faces down unruly Parliament, surviving vote of confidence hour before departing for potentially historic Camp David summit with Pres Clinton and Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat; motion to topple his wobbly coalition falls seven votes short of parliamentary majority of 61 after defection of three rightist parties leaves him head of enfeebled minority government of 42 members, barely third of 120-seat legislature; motion failed amid support from most Arab members of Parliament who have never been invited to join his government, and because of critical abstentions from United Torah Judaism, religious Orthodox party, and anti-Orthodox faction; photos (M)

block.p: A defiant Ehud Barak faced down an unruly Parliament tonight, surviving a vote of confidence just an hour before leaving for what he hopes will be historic peace talks with the Palestinians in Camp David, Md.

''From here, from united Jerusalem, the eternal capital of Israel, the greatest leaders of Israel went out to meet the greatest and most important of historic decisions in the history of the nation,'' Prime Minister Barak told Parliament, raising his voice above the jeers of the opposition.

A defiant Ehud Barak faced down an unruly Parliament tonight, surviving a vote of confidence just an hour before leaving for what he hopes will be historic peace talks with the Palestinians in Camp David, Md.

''From here, from united Jerusalem, the eternal capital of Israel, the greatest leaders of Israel went out to meet the greatest and most important of historic decisions in the history of the nation,'' Prime Minister Barak told Parliament, raising his voice above the jeers of the opposition.

''I wish to depart today from Jerusalem to Camp David in order to complete the labor of peacemaking that was begun by Menachem Begin and Yitzhak Rabin,'' he added, referring to two of his predecessors.
''I am not going alone,'' he continued, pointedly reminding the opposition yet again of his popular support.

But after the defections of three rightist parties from his year-old coalition, Mr. Barak was left the head of an enfeebled minority government of 42 members, barely a third of the 120-seat legislature.

A motion to topple Mr. Barak's wobbly coalition fell 7 votes short of a full parliamentary majority of 61, but still more of those actually voting voted against the government than for it, 54 to 52. Seven legislators abstained, and 7 others were not present.

The prime minister owes his lease on life to support from most Arab members of Parliament, who have never been invited to join his government, and to critical abstentions from United Torah Judaism, a religious Orthodox party, and Shinui, a resolutely anti-Orthodox faction.
''Barak is traveling to the summit defeated and alone!'' crowed a Likud party announcement of an opposition rally against the peace talks.

''I regret that the person who wanted to be the prime minister of everyone became in just one year the prime minister of almost no one, except maybe himself,'' Ariel Sharon, the Likud leader, taunted Mr. Barak in Parliament.
''You don't have a majority in the Knesset,'' he said. ''You don't have the support of the people.''
Mr. Barak dismissed his critics, and said, ''It was the people who sent me and gave me my mandate, and only the people will decide.''

Mr. Barak had planned to fly directly from Cairo to Washington today, after a morning meeting with the Egyptian President, Hosni Mubarak. Instead, with his coalition in shambles, he returned from Cairo to address Parliament before going on to the United States.
Mr. Barak took a commanding 56 percent majority in general elections last year, and since then his peace efforts have consistently had support in opinion surveys here.

Yet that support may be eroding. A poll in one leading newspaper today showed just 52 percent backing Mr. Barak's participation in the summit meeting, with 45 percent opposed. And in Parliament, his support is razor-thin: If United Torah Judaism and Shinui had joined the no-confidence majority, Mr. Barak would be heading tonight not toward Camp David, but toward new elections.
Israeli commentators groped for metaphors to describe his predicament, and his seemingly implacable confidence amid the wreckage of his once wide-reaching government.

''Never has an Israeli prime minister set out on such a historic mission with the support of such a pathetic coalition,'' Hemi Shaleven wrote in Maariv today. ''The co-pilots have activated their ejection seats one after the other, and Barak has been left alone, with his hands on the controls and the hysterical passengers in the back.''

Nahum Barnea, a political columnist at Yediot Ahronot, saw the prime minister heading toward the summit meeting as a kind of crazed alpinist, courageous but foolhardy. ''Barak wants to climb Everest without a rope, without a ladder and without a sweater,'' he said.

The Palestinians, meanwhile, watched today's parliamentary spectacle with a mixture of cynicism and dismay. Some saw Mr. Barak's apparent weakness as a Machiavellian maneuver to evade compromise on tough issues like Jerusalem and Jewish settlements.

''Is he really capable of making a peace agreement after the disintegration of his government last night?'' asked Mahmoud Dahlan, a top Palestinian security officer and a member of the Palestinian negotiating team.

Khaled al-Khatib, the director general of the Palestinian ministry of information, led a large protest in Gaza today against Jewish settlements and the Israeli troops that are deployed to protect the settlements.

The protest was held near the site of an accidental shooting death of a young Palestinian woman by Israeli soldiers two days ago. ''This is a symbolic sit-in to send a message to Israeli society, and to the Americans, that the Palestinian people will reject Camp David if the settlements stay,'' Mr. Khatib said.

In Jerusalem, near the prime minister's office, Natan Sharansky, Mr. Barak's interior minister until Sunday, held his own protest, collecting signatures for a petition in favor of a new unity government. Foreign Minister David Levy, who refused to join Mr. Barak's Camp David negotiating team, echoed the calls for a new and broad-based coalition.
The prevailing political wisdom day is that if the summit meeting produces a breakthrough, Mr. Barak will fly home and immediately schedule a referendum and new elections, perhaps simultaneously.
But if Camp David hits an impasse, the speculation is that he will try to create a unity government embracing Likud as well as his wayward former coalition partners.
Yet in Parliament today Mr. Barak and Mr. Sharon appeared to be going out of their way to scuttle any future collaboration.

Mr. Barak had conciliatory words for Jewish settlers in the West Bank and for the Orthodox Jews now arrayed against him. But staring at the Likud bench, he charged that many of his mainstream critics preferred the prospect of war to the possibility of reconciliation with the Arabs.

''These are the same prophets who warned us against Sadat's fraud when he came to visit Jerusalem,'' Mr. Barak said, referring to Anwar el-Sadat, the late Egyptian president. ''These are the same prophets who threatened us with katyushas on Ashkelon and Kfar Saba when Oslo was signed, and these are the same prophets who dared not leave Lebanon. These are also the same prophets who are unwilling to turn over every stone in an attempt to put an end to the cycle of blood.''

Interrupted repeatedly by heckling, the prime minister took the better part of an hour to deliver a speech of just 800 words. It is a role he seems almost to revel in: His trademark half-smile freezing between bemusement, disdain and anger, he waited each time for the jeers to subside. With his unscheduled address timed for the 5 p.m. television news programs, some experts saw his performance as a calculated attempt to draw a contrast with his raucous and bellicose critics.
But to others, it looked as if Mr. Barak had lost control.

''Go to elections,'' Mr. Sharon said, addressing the prime minister. ''Don't threaten us, and don't enlist others to threaten us with war and with rising violence, in order to force us into concessions.''
